conclusion: Analyze the motion of the particle in both the magnetic field and the electric field.
The particle is injected from the origin O with an initial velocity v0 at a 45° angle to the y-axis.
The velocity components are v0x = v0y = v0/√2.
In the magnetic field, the particle undergoes circular motion due to the Lorentz force.
The radius R of the circular path is given by R = mv0/qB.
The time period T for one complete revolution in the magnetic field is T = 2πm/qB.
The particle moves in a quarter-circle path in the magnetic field before entering the electric field.
The time t1 to travel this quarter-circle path is t1 = πm/(2qB).
In the electric field, the particle experiences a constant force in the negative y-direction.
The acceleration a in the y-direction is a = qE/m.
The velocity in the x-direction remains constant: vx = v0.
The velocity in the y-direction changes due to the electric field: vy = a t2.
The particle reaches point P(3L, L) with vx = v0 and vy = 0.
The time t2 to travel the distance 3L in the x-direction is t2 = 3L/v0.
The vertical displacement y in the electric field is y = (1/2) a t2^2.
Given y = L, we have L = (1/2) (qE/m) (3L/v0)^2.
Solving for E: E = 2mv0^2/(9qL).
The total time t is the sum of the time in the magnetic field and the time in the electric field.
The total time t is t = t1 + t2.
Substituting the values: t = πm/(2qB) + 3L/v0.
The total time taken for the particle to move from point O to point P is t = πm/(2qB) + 3L/v0.
